headline: Western Hemisphere Leaders Say They Won’t Recognize Venezuelan Elections
summary: Leaders from across the Americas centered their attention on Venezuela’s authoritarian government, as the U.S. and Latin America’s biggest nations said they wouldn’t recognize next month’s presidential election, calling it a farce.

headline: WPP Chief Executive Martin Sorrell Steps Down
summary: WPP’s Martin Sorrell is leaving his post as CEO following the conclusion of a probe into an allegation of personal misconduct, ending his more than three decades of leadership atop the world’s largest advertising company.

headline: U.N. Security Council Rejects Resolution Condemning U.S.-Led Airstrikes in Syria
summary: The United Nations Security Council rejected a Russian-backed resolution to condemn U.S.-led airstrikes in Syria after a two-hour debate in which the U.S. said it was poised to strike again if the government of Bashar al-Assad repeats its use of chemical weapons.

headline: Partisan Divide Defines Congressional Reaction to Syria Strikes
summary: Democrats complained that President Donald Trump lacked a larger strategy for how to end the Syria crisis, while Republicans applauded the U.S. action against President Bashar al-Assad’s alleged use of chemical weapons.

headline: French Publish Report Asserting Assad Used Chemical Weapons in Attack
summary: A French government report published Saturday concluded the regime of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad used chemical weapons in the deadly attack on civilians in Douma last week.

headline: What Mark Zuckerberg Didn’t Say About What Facebook Knows About You
summary: Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg told Congress you have ‘full access’ to the information the social network gathers about you, but it keeps some personal data that you can’t control.

headline: Michael Ferro Sells Tronc Stake to Relative of Former Chicago Tribune Owner
summary: Tronc Inc.’s largest shareholder, Michael Ferro, has agreed to sell his stake   to a descendant of the McCormick family that built the company’s flagship newspaper, the Chicago Tribune, into a media powerhouse in the early 20th century.

headline: Photos: U.S. and Allies Strike Syria
summary: The U.S., the U.K. and France launched airstrikes against sites associated with Syria’s chemical-weapons capabilities.

headline: Trump Tweets Congratulations to U.S. Allies on ‘Perfectly Executed Strike’
summary: President Donald Trump declared a “perfectly executed strike” on sites associated with Syrian chemical-weapon capabilities late Friday, a reprisal for an attack last week that killed at least 43 Syrian civilians.

headline: Justice for Scooter Libby
summary: Trump pardons a man Bush left behind on the battlefield.

headline: After Recession, Businesswoman Uses New Play Book to Expand
summary: Connecticut small-business owner Lana Corsano lost her home and company after the 2008 recession hit. As she grows a new firm, the lessons loom large.

headline: ‘Zuckerberg of Guns’ Pushes On
summary: Kai Kloepfer, inventor of a handgun with a fingerprint reader on the grip, appears to be the only one moving forward in the smart-gun industry.

headline: ‘L’epoque des Carrossiers: The Art and Times of the French Coachbuilders’ Review: Works of Art on Wheels
summary: An exhibition at the Mullin Automotive Museum looks at the bespoke Art Deco vehicles of the 1920s and ’30s.

headline: His Goal: Finish the Boston Marathon by Hand
summary: A quadriplegic handcyclist explains how he prepares for the most famous 26.2-mile race in the U.S.

headline: Cambridge University Pushes Back Against Facebook Scrutiny of Research Apps
summary: The uproar over how Facebook allowed a Cambridge University researcher to improperly harvest data on 87 million users has prompted a clash between the social network and the 800-year-old institution.

headline: A Divided Syria Reacts Wearily to Airstrikes From U.S. and Allies
summary: Syrians reacted with a mix of defiance and disappointment to early-morning missile strikes from the U.S., U.K. and France, showing how split the country has become over seven long years of civil war.

headline: U.S. Upholds Its Red Line in Syria, While Steering Clear of Russia’s
summary: In carrying out airstrikes in Syria, the U.S. and its allies were trying to maintain a careful balance: preventing the use of chemical weapons, without crossing Moscow’s red lines against toppling President Bashar al-Assad or targeting Russian forces.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: McCabe and a Lower Loyalty
summary: The IG report explains why the former FBI deputy director was fired.

headline: Business Is a Family Affair for Subway’s Suzanne Greco
summary: After the death of the CEO of Subway in 2015, his sister is battling to revive the sandwich chain.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: The Benefits of Bright Light for Hospital Patients
summary: Hospitals and nursing homes are turning up the lights in some patients’ rooms, amid new research on how light affects mood, energy and sleep

headline: Officials Acknowledge Assad Can Still Carry Out Chemical Attacks
summary: Allied missile strikes in Syria struck “at the heart” of Bashar al-Assad chemical-weapons program, the Pentagon said Saturday, but officials acknowledged that not all of the regime’s chemical infrastructure had been targeted.

headline: Strikes Spare Assad’s Conventional Arsenal
summary: Syria’s government retains its ability to conduct its most lethal attacks on rebels and civilians, even after the U.S., France and Britain launched missile strikes that the Pentagon said disabled the regime’s chemical-weapons capabilities.

headline: Allies United on Syria Despite Tensions
summary: The Trump administration’s close coordination with France and the U.K. to plan the strikes on the Syrian regime underscores an alignment between the U.S. and its European allies despite deep divisions over other issues.

headline: Trump Says Strikes Aimed at Ending Syria’s Use of Chemical Weapons
summary: President Donald Trump said the U.S., France and U.K. decision to launch strikes in Syria was aimed at the eliminating the nation’s ability to use chemical weapons, deterring the use and spread of such weapons and sending a message to two of Syria’s international patrons, Russia and Iran.

headline: The $24 Billion Job: An Energy CEO’s Quest to Reshape Gas Exports
summary: U.S. companies are scrambling to figure out how to sell more natural gas abroad. Tellurian Chief Executive Meg Gentle thinks she has a unique answer, but it is expected to cost $24 billion.

headline: Milos Forman, Oscar-Winning Director, Dies at 86
summary: Czech filmmaker Milos Forman, whose movies “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” and “Amadeus” won a deluge of Academy Awards, including best-director Oscars, died Saturday.

headline: Russia, Iran Denounce Airstrikes on Close Ally Syria
summary: The Syrian government’s allies strongly condemned the overnight airstrikes on Assad regime targets, with Iran’s supreme leader branding as “criminals” President Donald Trump, U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May and French President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: Today’s Chic Look? ‘Upcycled’ Clothes
summary: Many designers are ‘upcycling’—putting luxury spins on second-hand clothing, repurposing them under the mantle of sustainability to appeal to socially conscious customers

headline: ‘All the Politicians Rob’: Calls Rise in Brazil to End Officials’ Legal Shield
summary: The imprisonment of ex-President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva for corruption while many top Brazilian politicians remain in office despite graft charges against them is stoking fresh calls to end immunity for lawmakers.

headline: Syria Airstrikes Target Chemical Sites
summary: U.S., British and French forces targeted sites associated with Syria’s chemical-weapons capabilities, a reprisal for an attack last week that killed at least 43 civilians and injured hundreds more.

headline: School Is Expensive. Is It Worth It?
summary: For your kids, yes—at least assuming they graduate. But the author of ‘The Case Against Education’ says the benefits to society are vastly overstated.
